Review Title: Feels very corporate, for better or worse
Negative Reviews:
The big complaint is, the doors were thin so you can hear what's happening in the hall constantly, but they also SLAM shut so hard that you can feel it when anyone within 20 m of your room comes or goes.

This is the most corporate-feeling hostel I've ever stayed at. It felt like the place was run by a board room a thousand kilometers away. Some examples

- Drinks on the rooftop bar were super pricey (6 euro for a bottle of Alhambra beer, which I saw at a fancy restaurant the next day for 4.5 euro) - I was up there one night and it was totally dead, though I saw a few groups go up to the bar and then leave without buying anything. The next night was lively, but they had half the rooftop blocked off for a private event that guests were not allowed in.

- They charge 5 euro (charge, not deposit) to rent a towel, and it's another 5 euro if you want to swap it out for a fresh one.

- In the private rooms, there is no chest or drawers to organize your clothes, and the bathroom light is on a 5 minute timer (so it will turn off while you're in the shower unless you stick your hand out and wave). 

All kinds of little things like that which tell you as a guest "we don't want to spend any more money to make you comfortable than is absolutely necessary, and we will extract as much cash from you as we can while you're here"

Review Title: Chic, hip, and spotlessly clean; cloud-soft beds and thoughtful design
Negative Reviews: There were signs around the dining area that it was only for the use of paying customers, no outside food allowed. Does the hostel really want to force us to eat in the bedrooms? And this is a hostel, it's budget--most hostels include a kitchen so people can prepare their own meals, that's an assumption of most hostels, that you're preparing your own meals and probably eating cheaply. I'm also not a fan of en suite bathrooms in dorm bedrooms, it's a bit gross to me, but to their credit Generator keeps everything spotless and that's really the only way it's okay. Also, you have to bring your own lock for the lockers, so heads up.
Positive Reviews: The place is very chic, very cool, and well-run. Professional, friendly, helpful staff and--most importantly for any hostel--the place is always SPOTLESS. The bedrooms were really well-designed. As someone who stays at a lot of hostels, I know what works, what doesn't, and what's essential, and whoever designed Generator understood all of this. The individual lockers, which slide away neatly under the beds for storage, are capacious and include a hanger; there are hooks on the wall for towels and clothes; the showers have hooks and stools for putting your towel etc. (it seems basic, but it's amazing how many hostels lack these!). Each bed has an outlet, reading lamp, and a shelf and pocket for storage of personal items. The bedroom is painted a dark color and features blackout blinds so it's really conducive to a good sleep. The beds, pillows, and duvets were like clouds. It was pure joy to lie back on them after a long day out in the city. The showers have super nice shower heads. The lounge is hip, a good place to meet people, and always has great music playing on the speakers. There's also a rooftop bar with a great DJ, which is all cool in theory. In practice, unless you're actually ordering a drink it seems like you can't hang out there.

Positive Reviews:
I have been in Spain as an American Pilgrim on the Camino (Francés) de Santiago for 50 days and 50 nights starting on April 4, 2024. After initially staying 2 nights at a BnB in Madrid and the following night at a nice hotel in Pamplona, I stayed the remaining 47 nights in albergues, monasteries, hostels,  and finally the mega-hostel Generator Madrid for 2 nights.

All of these communal accommodations win my heart hands down with no comparison to the standard luxury hotel. The metropolitan atmosphere and sheer size of Generator Madrid (> 500 beds) does not diminish the underlying hospitality that was at the core of nearly all of the Camino albergues.

Note that the medieval pilgrims were largely provided lodging, food, and care by monasteries initially, and then also by community buildings called “Hospitales” in Spanish. I would not be surprised if the English word “hospitality” is derived from these Old World albergues that were called Hospitales. The main attendant at an albergue is called an “Hospitalero.”

At Generator Madrid, the service has been excellent. I arrived for check-in at 1 AM after 6-1/2 hours of bus and then high-speed train travel from Finisterre to Santiago to Madrid. The 24/7 reception desk was attended by a bilingual receptionist, Jesús, who was muy amable y animado, even at 2 AM.

I was the last guest to leave my 8-bed dormitory room at 10:15 AM, and the cafeteria staff, Rushyl and Jiana, were very welcoming, and did not rush me as I did not arrive for breakfast until 10:45 AM. Breakfast service ends at 11 AM.

The next time I am traveling in a metropolis anywhere in the world, I will seek out a hostel like Generator. I hope my wife will be open to this communal alternative.
